issue.title: Adding_CI.rst: Section on Circle CI
issue.body:
In Adding_CI.rst, we have a section on Circle CI.
It appears to me that we are no longer using Circle CI (the last build for coala/coala was 2 months ago and for coala/coala-bears was 6 months ago (which is still running on the unsupported CircleCI 1.0). Also the link to coala's circle.yml is broken.
There are two solutions to this:

If we are no longer using Circle CI (which appears to be the case) then the section or at least the link needs to be removed.
If we are using it, we still need to remove/update the link and also upgrade to Circle CI 2.0 for coala-bears (which should be done via a separate issue).

This issue requires some advice and input from the maintainers but regardless of that, this would be an issue that is suitable for newcomers.

issue.title: Travis build failing due to old version of golang
issue.body:
Travis build for coala/coala-bears/#2836 is failing with the following error:
# golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter
../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter/bexport.go:212: obj.IsAlias undefined (type *types.TypeName has no field or method IsAlias)
# golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/packagesdriver
../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/packagesdriver/sizes.go:94: undefined: types.SizesFor
The command ".ci/deps.go.sh" failed and exited with 2 during .

This problem persists if an old verion of Go language is used according to this issue which states that Go <= 1.8 is no longer supported.
Currently Travis CI testing is done on trusty, so either the latest version of golang needs to be manually installed in trusty images or an updated version of ubuntu needs to be used for testing.
Further input from maintainers is required to come at a conclusion.
EDIT: CI related issue area/ci

issue.title: Create a line length test helper
issue.body:
A line length test helper will take a chunk of source , and a regex, and verify the bear accepts source under the line length and rejects lines over the line length.
The max_line_length setting can be automatically determined by the lines in the source provided by the caller.  The bear should pass this test.
The regex is then used to increase the size of the source line lengths by 1 character, in accordance with the source language rules.
The helper confirms that the source was increased by 1 character only, and re-runs the bear, and expects it to fail.

issue.title: Nextgen-Core: Raise exception in core.run() when bear or result-callback raised an exception
issue.body:
Currently the core properly cleans up the failing bear and discards all dependent tasks and bears, and then swallows the exception.
However, coala (and other users) needs to know that something didn't work perfectly, for example returning an error code that some analysis was run, but couldn't complete due to errors.
I propose to write a custom exception that aggregates all those swallowed exceptions and is then raised in core.run().
class Exceptions(Exception):
    def __init__(self, exceptions):
        super().__init__('Multiple exceptions happened:\n' + '\n\n'.join(str(ex) for ex in exceptions)
        self.exceptions = exceptions
To make use of it, the core Session has another field, e.g. self.silent_errors or self.recovered_errors (or similar), where all components can put in their errors if they can recover from them. When exiting the run, the Session checks if exceptions were placed into self.silent_errors/self.recovered_errors, constructs an Exceptions instance with all of those errors and raises it in the main thread.
Acceptance criteria:

An exception is implemented that is capable of storing multiple exceptions and emitting an appropriate error message
core.run() raises this exception if at least one bear or result-callback failed. The raised exception provides information on all exceptions occurred and swallowed inside core.run().

issue.title: Add output mode to emit a unified diff
issue.body:
It can be useful to use coala to obtain a patch file of fixes that have been found by the bears.
For simplicity, unified diff output format should be the only format initially.
--json will be a bit of a guide on how to do this.
One way to solve this is to write a converter of the JSON output to a unified diff format, discarding all the non-fix results.

issue.title: The glob `*` does not match all bears
issue.body:
Many bears' result.origin is not just the name of the bear. For e.g.. ESLintBear has result.origin "ESLintBear (prettier/prettier)" and the glob * doesn't match anything with file seperators in it i.e. / or \, we have to use glob **. The PR #5017 fixes the issue with --apply-patches command line argument but if the .coafile has something like this
default_actions = *: ApplyPatchAction

This may not match all bears. This needs to be solved. Many things can be done to solve this eg:


The result.origin of those bears can be changed


I don't think that any user will think this through and use glob * specifically to ignore such bears so we can internally change all the glob * to **


We can prompt the user that some bears won't if they ever use the glob *


status/needs discussion on what is the best solution

issue.title: Bear Results not displayed in correct order
In `ask_for_action_and_apply()`, if `apply_single` is non-False, function should return when match is found
issue.body:
In the function ask_for_action_and_apply() in ConsoleInteraction.py, if the apply_single parameter is non-False, then the for loop inside it iterates through the entire metadata_list before returning False.
IMHO we should include a break statement inside the if block (which is in the for loop) such that the function may return after a match is found because there is no need to go through the remaining actions in metadata_list.

@akshatkarani if i delete this 8515861 commit. Would my PR gets deleted ?

No, you cannot delete a PR. Any PR. Only Close PR.
ok thanks

@akshatkarani if i delete this 8515861 commit. Would my PR gets deleted ?

It won't delete the PR, if you delete that commit.
You can delete that commit easily by using git interactive mode in terminal.
But, you need to squash your commits to one commit. Refer squashing section to know how to get into the interactive mode. Also, while you get into interactive mode, github provides some additional information on the terminal screen, please read those information carefully, as it will help you.
Also, use git commit --amend to add new local changes to your previous commit and then you can easily push this commit, without making an additional commits to the PR.

issue.title: Setting.py: Add end line number of setting
issue.body:
This adds end line number of a setting in coafile.
Related to #5044

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!
